lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six adjectives (long, short, small, big, new, old) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show pictures of school items in different sizes/conditions. Say: “This is big. This is small.” Students repeat and match to SB visuals.
stretchStrategies: Adjective Speed Draw – Call out two adjectives (e.g., long and old). On the board, quickly draw a random classroom item and say, “What is it? Describe it!” Students must work in pairs to write or say a full sentence using both adjectives (e.g., “The pencil is long and old.”). Encourage full sentences and creativity.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can say simple statements about school items using adjectives and the structure "The (item) is (adjective)."
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Point to items in SB or classroom. Say: “The pencil is long.” Students take turns making similar sentences about objects they see.
stretchStrategies: Adjective Speed Draw – Call out two adjectives (e.g., long and old). On the board, quickly draw a random classroom item and say, “What is it? Describe it!” Students must work in pairs to write or say a full sentence using both adjectives (e.g., “The pencil is long and old.”). Encourage full sentences and creativity.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “The ___ is ___.” to describe school items.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write the sentence frame: “The ___ is ___.” on the board. Fill in examples as a class using pictures (e.g., The ruler is short).
stretchStrategies: Adjective Speed Draw – Call out two adjectives (e.g., long and old). On the board, quickly draw a random classroom item and say, “What is it? Describe it!” Students must work in pairs to write or say a full sentence using both adjectives (e.g., “The pencil is long and old.”). Encourage full sentences and creativity.

items: Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
